bad.work: Christ Healing the Woman With an Issue of Blood

title.reg: Christ Healing the Woman With an Issue of Blood

titlestmt.title: Christ Healing the Woman With an Issue of Blood : electronic edition
titlestmt.principal: Editors: Morris Eaves, University of Rochester; Robert Essick, University of California, Riverside; and Joseph Viscomi, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
titlestmt.sponsor: The Library of Congress, the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the University of Rochester

filedesc.extent: 1 XML file approx. 8KB; 2 JPEG (ISO/IEC 10918) files ranging in size from 132KB to 1900KB
filedesc.publicationstmt: Chapel Hill: Eaves, Essick, Viscomi; Carolina Digital Library and ArchivesMarch 2011
filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive is pleased to announce the publication of an electronic edition of thirty-three of Blake’s water color illustrations to the Bible. All take their subjects from the New Testament and have been added to the twenty Old Testament subjects published in March 2010 as “Illustrations to the Bible, c. 1780-1824,” under Drawings and Paintings, Water Color Drawings. This new group is presented in our Preview mode, one that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (which provides detailed descriptions of Blake’s images).
Blake executed most of these New Testament water colors c. 1800-05 for his patron Thomas Butts. The exceptions are The Whore of Babylon of 1809 and The Parable of the Wise and Foolish Virgins in the Yale Center for British Art, datable to c. 1825. The subjects range from the childhood of Jesus to his ascension, the later history of his parents and one of his major followers, St. Paul, and a group of eight designs based on the Book of Revelation. While the illustrations of the life of Christ are fairly conventional in their subjects, in part because of the long tradition of picturing almost every event in the Gospels, individual motifs recall designs in Blake’s illuminated books and thus offer a window on Blake’s visual interpretation of the Bible. The illustrations of Revelation complement Blake’s intense engagement with apocalyptic events and images in his own poetry.
The selection of fifty-three biblical water colors now available in the Archive will be supplemented in the future with early works, such as Abraham and Isaac, datable to c. 1780, and will continue through Blake’s final biblical water colors, such as Moses Placed in the Ark of the Bulrushes.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with the University of Rochester, the continuing support of the Library of Congress, and the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

title.hi: Christ Healing the Woman With an Issue of Blood

objinfo.leafsize: 33.0 x 29.9 cm.The leaf is somewhat irregular.
objinfo.medium: pencil, pen and ink, and water color
objinfo.framelines: Although presently visible only bottom right and in the upper portion of the right margin, a single framing line probably exended around all four sides.

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Thomas Butts, probably commissioned and acquired by him from Blake, c. 1803-05; by inheritance in 1845 to Thomas Butts, Jr.; offered at Sotheby's, 26 June 1852, lot 156, titled "Touching the Garment" (10s. to "Butts," thus indicating that the lot was bought-in if Butts was the vendor); William Smith by 1863; given by Smith in 1871 to the Victoria and Albert Museum.

desc.objtitle: Christ Healing the Woman With an Issue of Blood, Object 1 (Butlin 482)

objnote.p: Blake signed the work lower left with his monogram; see the textual transcription. The ink inscription lower right, "1689. 72," is not by Blake. This is an abbreviated version of the Victoria and Albert Museum accession number; it was very probably written on the work by someone at the Victoria and Albert Museum shortly after its acquisition of the work.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design illustrates Matthew 9:20-22. Toward the left of the design stands Jesus in contrapposto, facing forward but slightly to the left. He has long, curly hair and a beard, as well as a halo-like radiance around his head and a possible aura around the upper part of his body. He wears a gown. His arms are at his side, with his right arm bent slightly, palm out with fingers slightly spread. His left leg is bent and on tiptoe. To the left of Jesus stand two children in the foreground. The leftmost child appears to be a young gowned girl with long, curly hair, standing in contrapposto so that she faces forward and slightly left but looks up to the right at Jesus. Her arms are at her side, though her right arm is slightly bent and she holds the hand of the figure to the right with her left hand. Her left leg is bent and perhaps on tiptoe. Her body posture mimics that of Jesus. The rightmost of these two figures appears to be that of a young boy with short, curly hair. He wears a shirt with buttons and a pair of knee-length breeches. He also stands in contrapposto so that his body faces forward and slightly left, but he looks up to the right—perhaps at Jesus. His left arm is at his side, but his right arm is bent to hold the hand of the figure to the left. His left leg is bent and extended back slightly, as well as on tiptoe. In the background to the left of Jesus stand three gowned figures, all facing forward but looking to the right, perhaps at Jesus. The leftmost figure is that of a male with short, curly hair and a beard. The middle figure appears to be that of an old male with short, curly hair and a beard. His left arm is at his side and his mouth may be slightly open. The rightmost figure of this group appears to be a young male (or possibly a female) with long hair. His left arm appears to be at his side and his mouth may be slightly open. In the foreground to the right of Jesus stand six gowned children. The leftmost child appears to be that of a young girl with long, slightly curly hair. She faces forward and looks up and to the left, perhaps at Jesus. Her arms are bent upward with her palms together as though in prayer or supplication. The second-to-left child of this group appears to be a boy with long, curly hair. He faces forward and left, perhaps looking at Jesus. His arms appear to be at his side. The third-to-left child of this group appears to be a girl with long, curly hair. She faces left and looks up, perhaps at Jesus. Her arms are bent upward with her palms together as though in prayer or supplication. Her left leg is extended backward slightly and on tiptoe. The third-to-right child appears to be a boy with short, curly hair. His right arm appears to be at his side. He faces forward and to the left and looks slightly down. He may be smiling slightly. The second-to-right child appears to be a girl with long, wavy hair who faces forward and to the left, perhaps looking at Jesus. Her arms appear to be at her side and her mouth may be slightly open. The rightmost child appears to be a girl, facing away and slightly left, but with her head turned slightly right. She appears to have long hair pulled up into a bun. Her arms are at her side but bent upward slightly. Her left leg is extended backward and on tiptoe, suggesting that she may be walking. In the foreground to the right of Jesus kneels an old woman, facing left and down. She bends forward or hunches over slightly. She wears a gown and a veil covering her hair. Her left arm is raised horizontally (relative to her body) and points downward, perhaps reaching for the hem of Jesus's garment. Her right arm is bent upward and holds her gown to her stomach. In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. The leftmost figure is that of a male with short, curly hair, facing forward and to the left, perhaps looking at Jesus. His right arm appears to be at his side, while his left arm is bent, with the left hand held to his chest. All that is visible of the second-to-left figure is the head of an old male with a long beard, but apparently bald crown. He faces forward and to the left and looks down slightly. All that is visible of the third-to-left figure is the head of an old male with a long beard. He faces to the left and down. The fourth-to-left figure is that of a female with long, slightly curly hair, perhaps pulled back into a bun. She faces forward and slightly left and looks down, perhaps at the children in the foreground. Her arms are at her side and bent; with her right arm she holds the arm of the leftmost figure of the group, while in her left arm, she holds an infant. The baby has long hair and is seated on its mother's arm. Its gender is indeterminable, and it faces away and slightly left. Its left arm is at its side and its left leg is bent. All that is visible of the third-to-right figure of this group is long hair. The second-to-right figure is that of a male with short, slightly curly hair and a beard. He faces to the left and forward, perhaps looking at Jesus. The rightmost figure of the group is that of a woman, facing left and perhaps looking at Jesus. She has long hair pulled up into a bun and holds her bent left arm to her chest. The ground below the figures has slight indications of vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: Toward the left of the design stands Jesus in contrapposto, facing forward but slightly to the left. He has long, curly hair and a beard, as well as a halo-like radiance around his head and a possible aura around the upper part of his body. He wears a gown. His arms are at his side, with his right arm bent slightly, palm out and fingers slightly spread. His left leg is bent and on tiptoe.

To the left of Jesus stand two children in the foreground. The leftmost child appears to be a young gowned girl with long, curly hair, standing in contrapposto so that she faces forward and slightly left but looks up to the right at Jesus. Her arms are at her side, though her right arm is slightly bent and she holds the hand of the figure to the right with her left hand. Her left leg is bent and perhaps on tiptoe. Her body posture mimics that of Jesus.

To the left of Jesus stand two children in the foreground. The rightmost of these two figures appears to be that of a young boy with short, curly hair. He wears a shirt with buttons and a pair of knee-length breeches. He also stands in contrapposto so that his body faces forward and slightly left, but he looks up to the right—perhaps at Jesus. His left arm is at his side, but his right arm is bent to hold the hand of the figure to the left. His left leg is bent and extended back slightly, as well as on tiptoe.

In the background to the left of Jesus stand three gowned figures, all facing forward but looking to the right, perhaps at Jesus. The leftmost figure is that of a male with short, curly hair and a beard.

In the background to the left of Jesus stand three gowned figures, all facing forward but looking to the right, perhaps at Jesus. The middle figure appears to be that of an old male with short, curly hair and a beard. His left arm is at his side and his mouth may be slightly open.

In the background to the left of Jesus stand three gowned figures, all facing forward but looking to the right, perhaps at Jesus. The rightmost figure of this group appears to be a young male (or possibly a female) with long hair. His left arm appears to be at his side and his mouth may be slightly open.

In the foreground to the right of Jesus stand six gowned children. The leftmost child appears to be that of a young girl with long, slightly curly hair. She faces forward and looks up and to the left—perhaps at Jesus. Her arms are bent upward with her palms together as though in prayer or supplication.

In the foreground to the right of Jesus stand six gowned children. The second-to-left child of this group appears to be a boy with long, curly hair. He faces forward and left, perhaps looking at Jesus. His arms appear to be at his side.

In the foreground to the right of Jesus stand six gowned children. The third-to-left child of this group appears to be a girl with long, curly hair. She faces left and looks up, perhaps at Jesus. Her arms are bent upward with her palms together as though in prayer or supplication. Her left leg is extended backward slightly and on tiptoe.

In the foreground to the right of Jesus stand six gowned children. The third-to-right child appears to be a boy with short, curly hair. His right arm appears to be at his side. He faces forward and to the left and looks slightly down. He may be smiling slightly.

In the foreground to the right of Jesus stand six gowned children. The second-to-right child appears to be a girl with long, wavy hair who faces forward and to the left, perhaps looking at Jesus. Her arms appear to be at her side and her mouth may be slightly open.

In the foreground to the right of Jesus stand six gowned children. The rightmost child appears to be a girl, facing away and slightly left, but with her head turned slightly right. She appears to have long hair pulled up into a bun. Her arms are at her side but bent upward slightly. Her left leg is extended backward and on tiptoe, suggesting that she may be walking.

In the foreground to the right of Jesus kneels an old woman, facing left and down. She bends forward or hunches over slightly. She wears a gown and a veil covering her hair. Her left arm is raised horizontally (relative to her body) and points downward, perhaps reaching for the hem of Jesus's garment. Her right arm is bent upward and holds her gown to her stomach.

In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight gowned figures. The leftmost figure is that of a gowned male with short, curly hair, facing forward and to the left, perhaps looking at Jesus. His right arm appears to be at his side, while his left arm is bent, with the left hand held to his chest.

In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. All that is visible of the second-to-left figure is the head of an old male with a long beard, but apparently bald crown. He faces forward and to the left and looks down slightly.
In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. All that is visible of the third-to-left figure is the head of an old male with a long beard. He faces to the left and down.

In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. The fourth-to-left figure is that of a gowned female with long, slightly curly hair, perhaps pulled back into a bun. She faces forward and slightly left and looks down—perhaps at the children in the foreground. Her arms are at her side and bent—with her right arm she holds the arm of the leftmost figure of the group, while in her left arm, she holds an infant. There may be a belt at her waist.

In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. The fourth-to-right figure is that of a gowned infant long hair and seated on its mother's arm. Its gender is indeterminable, and it faces away and slightly left. Its left arm is at its side and its left leg is bent.
In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. All that is visible of the third-to-right figure of this group is long hair.

In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. The second-to-right figure is that of a male with short, slightly curly hair and a beard. He faces to the left and forward, perhaps looking at Jesus. He appears to be gowned.

In the background to Jesus's right stands a group of eight figures. The rightmost figure of the group is that of a woman, facing left and perhaps looking at Jesus. She has long hair pulled up into a bun and holds her bent left arm to her chest. She is gowned.
The ground below the figures has slight indications of vegetation. The feet of several figures cast shadows.
